titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Gregory Zilboorg Papers
titlestmt.author: by Lisa Conathan

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Wednesday January 23, 2019 at 04:20

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: Correspondence, writings and photographs that document the translations, psychoanalytic practice and scholarship of Gregory Zilboorg, the relationship between Gregory and Margaret Zilboorg (neé Stone), and Gregory Zilboorg's photographic portraiture.

langmaterial.language: Materials in English, Russian and French.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Gregory Zilboorg Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Gregory Zilboorg Papers. Yale Collection of American Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

p.ref: James and Eugenia Zilboorg Papers, YCAL MSS 259

bioghist.head: Gregory Zilboorg, 1890-1959
bioghist.p: Gregory Zilboorg was a psychoanalyst and historian of psychiatry. His many writings and lectures situated psychiatry within a broad sociological and humanistic context at a time when psychoanalysis was gaining importance in literary culture.

Zilboorg was born in Kiev on December 25, 1890 and studied medicine in Petrograd (St. Petersburg). In 1917 he served in the Ministry of Labor for two presidents (Aleksandr Kerenskii and Georgii L'vov). In 1919 he emigrated to the United States and for a time translated plays from Russian to English while studying medicine at Columbia University. After graduating in 1926, he worked at the Bloomingdale Hospital and eventually established a psychoanalitic practice in New York City. From the 1930s onward, Zilboorg produced several volumes of lasting importance on the history of psychiatry. The Medical Man and the Witch During the Renaissance began as the Noguchi lectures at Johns Hopkins University in 1935. This volume was followed by History of Medical Psychology in 1941 and Sigmund Freud in 1951.

Zilboorg's analytic practice brought him into contact with prominent figures in New York's literary and theater milieu. His patients included Marshall Field, George Gershwin, Lillian Hellman, Ralph Ingersoll, Kay Swift and James Warburg. Another of his patients, Moss Hart, drew on his experience in psychoanalysis when writing the musical Lady in the Dark .

Zilboorg was also an avid photographer. His portraits of John Farquhar Fulton and Henry Sigerist were featured in obituaries published in the Journal of the History of Medicine and Allied Sciences, Inc .
Zilboorg married Ray Liebow in 1919 and they had two children (Nancy and Gregory, Jr.). He married Margaret Stone in 1946 and they had three children (Caroline, John and Matthew).

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection consists of three series: Correspondence, Writings, and Photographs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The correspondence, writings and photographs in this collection document the translations, psychoanalytic practice and scholarship of Gregory Zilboorg, the relationship between Gregory and Margaret Zilboorg (neé Stone) and Gregory Zilboorg's photographic portraiture. Most of the papers date from the 1940s and early 1950s and document Zilboorg's personal life and writings (including translations and writings on the history of psychiatry). The papers illustrate the work of a prominent analyst at a time when psychoanalysis had a significant influence on the New York literary circle in which Zilboorg worked.

Writings (Series II) consists of notes, drafts and proofs of several of Zilboorg's publications. The publications include short articles and lectures, books ( History of Medical Psychology and Sigmund Freud ), translations from Russian to English (including the play "He, the One Who Gets Slapped") and two original playscripts.

Photographs (Series III) includes informal snapshots and studio portraits of Gregory Zilboorg and several portraits of others (likely by Zilboorg). Subjects of these portraits include Diego Rivera and Jean Piaget.

While the papers described here do not date from Gregory Zilboorg's early years in Kiev and Petrograd (St. Petersburg), readers may consult the James and Eugenia Zilboorg Papers, YCAL MSS 259 for his letters to his brother James Zilboorg, 1915-1959.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series I consists of two subseries: Professional and Personal. Professional correspondence is arranged alphabetically and reflects Zilboorg's organization of his files. While most correspondence is filed under the name of correspondent or patient, some filing is based on subject (for example, letters related to Zilboorg's passport are filed under "P"). Correspondence related to History of Medical Psychology is filed in Series II.
Most personal correspondence is undated and remains in the order in which it was received.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Professional correspondence dates mostly from 1940 to1941 and includes incoming, outgoing and third party letters. The topics addressed include Zilboorg's professional travel, speaking engagements, publishing arrangements, financial matters and medical patients. While Zilboorg discusses patient cases in his correspondence, the papers do not include patient records or case files.

Personal correspondence consists chiefly of letters between Zilboorg and his future wife, Margaret Norton Stone. Zilboorg and Stone met in 1940 when Stone became Zilboorg's research secretary. They married in 1946. There is also one folder of general correspondence addressed to Gregory and Margaret Zilboorg. This folder includes several letters of congratulations on their marriage.

did.unittitle: General correspondence A-Z, addressed to Gregory and Margaret Zilboorg
did.physloc: Also stored in: Oversize Box 8, folder 93.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Letters signed by first name only are filed at the end of the folder

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes correspondence related to an essay Margaret Stone wrote for PM in 1941

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series II consists of five subseries: Background Materials, Articles and Lectures, Books, Translations, and Other Writings. Each subseries is arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The writings in Series II include notes, drafts and proofs for several of Zilboorg's publications and lectures. Background materials consist of notes from articles and books that Zilboorg read prior to 1925. Articles and lectures consist of typescripts, printed versions and holograph drafts of lectures and short articles. Authorship is not certain for one pseudonymous article, "A Psychiatrist Looks at Hitler." Books consist of drafts, proofs and correspondence for two of Zilboorg's major publications, History of Medical Psychology and Sigmund Freud . Translations consist of typescripts for three plays that Zilboorg translated from Russian to English. Other writings include typescripts of two original plays, a transcript of Isaac Ray's 1828 diary, complete bibliographies of Zilboorg's work and an obituary.

did.unittitle: "Most Common Mechanisms met with in Psychopathology," corrected typescript
"The Medical Man and the Witch During the Renaissance," abstract, printed version
"The Ever-unfinished Chain of Learning," holograph and program
"Psychology of the Criminal act," broadside for a lecture at Boston University
"He, The One Who Gets Slapped," by Leonid Andreyev, printed version
"The Violins of Autumn," by I. Sourgoucheff, typescript
"The Main Thing," by N. N. Yevreynov, typescript
Transcript of the diary of Isaac Ray from 1828, typescript
"Gregory Zilboorg -- A Memorial, 1891-1959," reprints from the American Journal of Psychiatry

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series III is arranged alphabetically by subject.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains snapshots and portraits of Gregory Zilboorg, Margaret Zilboorg and others. Gregory Zilboorg counted photography among his interests and it is likely that he took many of the photographic portraits in this series. He is, however, definitively identified as the photographer for only three of them.

Pichel, Irving, portrait by an unknown photographer (not Zilboorg)
